Question 9:
ANSWER GOES HERE
A block element will always start on a new line, an inline element does not start on a new line. Inline CSS can be used to modify specific parts of an element with <span>. An example of a block element is <div> which creates a new line and creates a division which we can style in CSS. 
ex: <div class="hello"><h1>Hello World</h1></div> 
.hello {
   text-align:center;
}
creates a block with Hello World, while defining it as a division and assigning it a class.

Question 11:
1) It is easier to maintain and less confusing to read. Having two languages in the same file can make it difficult or confusing to read and modify.
2) You can reuse the same CSS file (and the layout of its contents) across multiple webpages
3) separating enhances organization
